metadata.title: Biosynthesis of nano bimetallic Ag/Pt alloy from Crocus sativus L. extract: Biological efficacy and catalytic activity

sections.text:
Contents lists available at ScienceDirect
Journal of Photochemistry & Photobiology, B: Biology
journal homepage: www.elsevier.com/locate/jphotobiol
Biosynthesis of nano bimetallic Ag/Pt alloy from Crocus sativus L. extract: Biological efficacy and catalytic activity Min Yanga,b, Fang Luc, Tingting Zhouc, Jianjun Zhaod,⁎, Chuanbo Dinge,⁎, Ali Fakhrif,⁎, Vinod Kumar Guptag a School of Traditional Chinese Medicine, Changchun University of Chinese Medicine, Changchun 130017, China b School of Traditional Chinese Materia Medica, Jilin Agricultural Science and Technology University, Jilin 132101, China c Department of Clinical Pathology, Jilin Kingmed for Clinical Laboratory Co., Ltd, Changchun 130000, China d Department of Encephalology, Affiliated Hospital of Changchun University of Chinese Medicine, Changchun 130021, China e School of Chinese Medicinal Materials, Jilin Agricultural University, Changchun 130118, China f Department of Chemistry, Nano Smart Science Institute, Tehran, Iran g Department of Biological Sciences, Faculty of Science, King Abdulaziz University, Jeddah, Saudi Arabia
A R T I C L E I N F O
Keywords: Crocus sativus L. Bimetallic nanoparticles Biological Catalytic
A B S T R A C T
In this project, silver‑platinum (AgPt) nanoparticles were prepared by using the Crocus sativus L. plant ethanolic extract. The AgPt nanoparticles were characterized by applying the various method as ultraviolet-visible and infrared spectroscopy, electron microscopy, and X-ray diffraction analysis. The morphology structural indicated that the AgPt nanoparticles were spherical particles with diameter about 36.0 nm. The FTIR spectroscopy shows the efficient stabilization of the AgPt nanoparticles by phytoconstituents. The Ag and AgPt nanoparticles have polyphenolic content, lower than the flavonoids and proanthocyanins contents. The AgPt nanoparticles depicted the highest antioxidant properties compared to the Ag nanoparticles and ascorbic acid. The results showed that the AgPt nanoparticles had a high antioxidant properties. In addition, the AgPt nanoparticles demonstrated the substantial antimicrobial and cytotoxic activities against pathogenic microbes and MCF-7 breast cancer cell line. The environmental chemistry analysis depicts that methyl orange can be degraded from water by catalytic degradation process with sodium borohydride. The AgPt nanoparticles were prosperous in catalytic degrading methyl orange following a first order kinetic model.

sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text:
Nowadays, metal nanoparticles have possessed the consideration of researchers, due to the catalytic, optic and electric properties [1–3]. The deployment of noble metal nanoparticles in biological usage have the common therapy toward diseases or cancer [4,5]. The presence of dangerous chemicals for preparation and formation process have unsuitable effect in medical usage [6,7]. Thereupon, the green synthesis method have been investigated by using plants, microbes, agrowastes, pigments and enzyme for preparation of the noble metal nanoparticles [8,9].
The bimetallic nanoparticles has been ascribed to their hybrid performance to mix the attributes of two metals [10]. The bimetallic silver‑platinum have been widely studied in scientific reports due to the highest potential from Ag and Pt [11,12]. In the previous studies, the antioxidant/antimicrobial efficiency of Ag nano materials [13,14] and
the cytotoxic properties of Pt nano materials have been presented [15], and can be a good approach for disease treatment. Thereupon, there is a need to environmentally friendly method for preparation of Ag and Pt nano materials. Recently, the ethanolic extract of different plant were used for biosynthesis of bimetallic alloys nanoparticles [16]. Crocus sativus L. (saffron) is an important medicinal plant. Various biological activities such as antioxidant and antimicrobial activities have been attributed to extracts of Crocus sativus L. [17,18]. In previous studies showed different extract for synthesis mono or bimetallic nanoparticles. Elegbede and et al., presented the new synthesis with fungal xylanases for preparation of AgeAu bimetallic nanoparticle [19]. Adebayo and et al., showed the Persea Americana fruit peel extract was used for synthesis of Ag, Au, and AgAu nanoparticles [20]. Lateef et al., depicted the preparation of silver‑gold nanopowders by using the Cola nitida pod extracts for antimicrobial and Thrombolytic Applications [21]. Ojo et al., illustrated the Bacillus Safensis LAU was used to preparation of
https://doi.org/10.1016/j.jphotobiol.2020.112025 Received 5 May 2020; Received in revised form 5 September 2020; Accepted 9 September 2020

Journal of Photochemistry & Photobiology, B: Biology 212 (2020) 112025
Available online 12 September 2020 1011-1344/ © 2020 Elsevier B.V. All rights reserved.
T
AgeAu nanoparticles and applied for Anti-Coagulant and Thrombolytic studies [22]. Adebayo et al., evaluated the synthesis method of SilverGold Alloy Nanoparticles via Opuntia ficus-indica extract and used in antimicrobial and antioxidant activity [23]. Akintayo et al., studied on the synthesis animal fur-mediated silver nanoparticles for cytogenotoxicity activity [24].
In new studies, metal nano materials were presented as impressive catalysts for degradation of chemical compounds [25]. Ghosh et al., investigated the bimetallic AueAg nanoparticles are great and stable catalysts for degradation of different dye compounds [26]. In this research, the bimetallic AgPt nanoparticles were prepared by using the reducing potentials of Crocus sativus L extract via a simple method. In recent reports, the determination of metals in Crocus sativus L. was investigated. The results showed that the mineral elements were detected. The Crocus sativus are resources of calcium, potassium, iron manganese, magnesium and zinc were determined which that are needful for human health. Moreover, some of heavy metals were detected. The concentrations were the lowest, meet the national standards and safely for humans [27,28]. Therefore, there are not any heavy metal contamination from Crocus sativus L. plant. The AgPt nanoparticles from Crocus sativus L. extract was characterized by TEM, FTIR and UV–Visible spectral analysis. The prepared AgPt nanoparticles were examined for biological effects, and catalysis activities.

sections.heading: 2.1. Materials
sections.text: All chemical compounds were procured from Merck Co., Germany. The Crocus sativus L. was obtained from Qaen in the South Khorasan from Iran.

sections.heading: 2.2. Bio-synthesis of the of AgPt nanoparticles
sections.text:
The ground powder of Crocus sativus L. plant (1.0 g) was dispersed in the ethanol (120 mL) and annealed at 75 °C in during 40 min and then refined. The Crocus sativus L. extract was preserved at 5 °C until future apply.
In order to preparation of silver‑platinum (AgPt) nanoparticles, 25 mL of ethanolic Crocus sativus L. extract was augmented to the 50 mL of AgNO3 (1 mM) and K2PtCl4 (1 mM) solution and vigorously stirred at 100 °C for 1 h. The process was monitored with ultra-violet-visible spectroscopy (Shimadzu, UV-1900). The sample was formed and washed two times to eliminate of impurities. The product were dried at 70 °C for 60 min and calcined at 350 °C for 2 h to achieve the silver‑platinum nanoparticles (Sch. 1). The same procedure was applied without platinum salt to preparation of Ag nanoparticles.

sections.heading: 2.3. Systematics of analysis
sections.text: The functional agents of bio-synthesized nanoparticles were investigated by using the FTIR spectra (PerkinElmer; 4000–500 cm−1). The transmission electron microscopy (TEM) (JEOL JEM 2100) was recorded to evaluation of morphological information. The Dynamic Light Scattering techniques (Malvern Zetasizer) was used for determination of particle size ranges. Phytochemical experiment was analyzed by using the Flash Spectrophotometer, Thermo Scientific.

sections.heading: 2.4. Phytochemical experiment
sections.text:
The Folin-Ciocalteu route was used for evaluation of total phenolic content (TPC) [29]. The gallic acid solution (0.5–1.5 mg/mL, 25 μL) and nanoparticles solution (1.5 mg/mL, 25 μL) was mixed with 75 μL of reagent in plates. In continue, the sodium carbonate (8.0%, 100 μL) was augmented to the mixture and incubated at 37 °C for 2 h. The color appearance was distinguished by using the spectrophotometer
(750 nm). All test were conducted in 3rd times. The aluminum chloride method was used to determination of total flavonoid content (TFC) [29]. The prepared nanoparticles solution (1.5 mg/mL, 25 μL) and standard catechin (0.5–1.5 mg/mL, 25 μL) was placed into each well plate, separately. In continue, 10 μL of the 7.5% sodium nitrite and 180 μL of double-distilled water were augmented. After 10 min, aluminum chloride (8.5%, 10 μL) was augmented and kept for 10 min at room temperature. The sodium hydroxide (5.0%, 45 μL) was augmented and incubated for 30 min. All test were conducted in 3rd times. The absorbance was distinguished at 415 nm.
The proanthocyanidin content was determined as the prepared nanoparticles solution (1.5 mg/mL, 25 μL) and standard catechin (0.5–1.5 mg/mL, 25 μL) was placed into each well plate, separately. The vanillin methanol (160 μL, 5%) and hydrochloric acid (80 μL) were added to the above mixture and stand at room temperature for 30 min (Abs. at 515 nm) [29].

sections.heading: 2.5. Antioxidant activities
sections.text:
The radical scavenging performance of the prepared nanoparticles were analyzed by using DPPH and ABTS radical agent. All test were conducted in 3rd times [30]. The performance was determined through:
= ×Scavenging activity Abs Abs
Abs (%) . . . 100control sample control
The test sample contains the stock solution (80 μL) and DPPH solution (80 μL) was mixed together to produce 160 μL solution and incubated at room temperature for 1 h. Ascorbic acid was applied as the control group.
The ABTS radical was produced by addition of ABTS (6 mM) to potassium persulfate (3 mM) and stirred for 8 h at room temperature in the dark system. The methanolic ABTS solution (80 μL) was mixed with extract/standard (20 to 360 μg/mL, 80 μL). The mixture was incubated for 10 min in dark condition. The absorbance was detected at 725 nm.

sections.heading: 2.6. Bactericide and fungicide activity
sections.text: The antimicrobial efficiency of the prepared AgPt nanoparticles was experimented through the serial dilution method toward one and as Staphylococcus aureus (G+ bacteria), Escherichia coli (G− bacteria), and Candida albicans. The AgPt nanoparticles were diluted with a 12 h culture with nanoparticles concentration 10–800 μg/mL and incubated at 38 °C for 24 h. The Resazurin dye was used as microbial growth indicator. All test were conducted in 3rd times [31].

sections.heading: 2.7. Cytotoxicity assay
sections.text: The cytotoxicity properties of the prepared nanoparticles was investigated by using the human breast cancer (MCF-7) and embryonic kidney (HEK 293) cell lines (MTT reduction). Cells were placed into a plate, and incubated for one day at 38 °C under 6% dioxide carbon. After this process, the cells were therapized with different nanomaterial concentrations for one day. The MTT solution (5 mg/mL) was used for plate treatment for 5 h, and then dimethyl sulfoxide was added to solve any residual of the formazan dyes. The performance was detected at 565 nm by using the ELISA spectrophotometer [32].

sections.heading: 2.8. Catalytic tests
sections.text:
The catalytic performances of the synthesized Ag and AgPt nanoparticles is investigated on the reduction of methyl orange (MO) by sodium borohydride. 3 mL of NaBH4 (0.05 M) is added to 20 mL of MO (10.0 mg/L). The prepared Ag and AgPt nanoparticles are augmented to this solution and stirred for different time. Then, the UV–vis spectrophotometer have been used for distinguish the residual of MO
concentration (λ = 465 nm) after separation from the prepared catalyst.

sections.heading: 2.9. Statistical studies
sections.text: Statistical of the data (average ± SD) was conducted applying the one t-test from ANOVA (SPSS software program). This study considered P < 0.05 for significantly various groups.

sections.heading: 3.1. Characterization of the synthesized nanomaterials
sections.text:
The eco-friendly properties of the synthesized nanoparticles was confirmed by the presence of the polyphenols, flavonoids, and proanthocyanidins. The bio process reduction of silver and platinum ions to form AgPt nanoparticles from ethanolic extract of Crocus sativus L. was studied via UV–vis spectrophotometer in during 1 h as time reaction. The change color was confirmed the preparation of AgPt nanoparticles (Scheme 1).
The UV–vis spectra of the ethanolic extract of Crocus sativus L. capped AgPt nanoparticles illustrated the plasmon resonance at 420 nm after three days (Fig. 1A). It can be seen, the spectra of the core-shell AgPt nanoparticles has two bands, which that shows formation of silver and the reduction of the silver was more than platinum [33]. The silver nanoparticles and platinum nanoparticles indicated an absorption peak at near 415 nm. The several peaks (500–700 nm) could be detected the bio-organic oxidation material due to presence of the ethanolic extract of Crocus sativus L. [33].
The TEM image of the as bio-prepared AgPt nanopowders from the dried ethanolic Crocus sativus L. extract indicated mainly spherical shaped of AgPt nanoparticles (Fig. 2C) with an average particles size of 36.0 nm. The average particle size distinguished for spherical Ag nanoparticles as 32.0 nm in Fig. 2B. The EDS spectra indicated peak signals from silver and platinum, demonstrating the presence of two metals in the bio-prepared nanoparticles. The bright spots in the selected area electron diffraction analysis indicated the crystalline structure of the bio-synthesized AgPt nanoparticles (Fig. 2C), which that showed the ethanolic extract of Crocus sativus L. performance for synthesis of the AgPt nanoparticles. The stability of the bio-synthesized Ag nanoparticles and AgPt nanoparticles was distinguished by using dynamic light scattering analysis. The bio-synthesized Ag nanoparticles and AgPt nanoparticles indicated an insignificant zeta-potential value in 60 h (Fig. 2D). The negative zeta-potential was related to the strong adsorption of phytochemicals material from formation of nanoparticles, which that improved the stability and decreased the aggregation. The FTIR spectra of the dried ethanolic extract of Crocus sativus L. (Fig. 3) depicted the several peaks at 3340 cm−1 (-OH group due the presence of phenolics, carbohydrates, and flavonoids), 2921 cm−1 (CeH), 1715 cm−1 (C=O), 1610 cm−1 (NeH), 1370 cm−1 (OeH), 1288 cm−1 (CeN), and a strong peak at 1030 cm−1 (CeC). The spectra of the biosynthesized Ag nanoparticles and AgPt nanoparticles were same to dried ethanolic extract of Crocus sativus L. due to the capping and
nanoparticles stabilization from the ethanolic extract of Crocus sativus L. The infrared intensity of the Ag nanoparticles and AgPt nanoparticles peaks was decreased due to the concentration of ethanolic extract of Crocus sativus L. was reduced in the conjugate process via the prepared nanoparticles [33].
Scheme 1. The mechanism for the phytochemicals on the biosynthesis of AgPt nanoparticles

sections.heading: 3.2. Phytochemical analysis
sections.text:
The polyphenolic materials in the bio Ag nanoparticles and AgPt nanoparticles from of Crocus sativus L. by quantifying the phytochemical content at 1 h process. The phytochemical data is significance to the evaluation of reaction mechanism. In near end times, polyphenolic compounds have been detected to possess the efficiency to donate an e−, play as metal chelators, and oxygen quenchers [34]. For the bio-
synthesized Ag nanoparticles and AgPt nanoparticles, the TPC (30.55 ± 0.54, and 15.21 ± 0.22 mg GAE/g) and TFC (350.30 ± 0.05 and 130.41 ± 0.13 mg QE/g) amounts was detected, respectively. The proanthocyanidin amount of Ag nanoparticles enhanced (Table 1). The reduction content of the TPC, TFC, and PA for the AgPt nanoparticles after 1 h of preparation could be ascribed to the nucleophilic properties of the phytochemicals materials, which that it's important for chelation and stabilization of metals [34]. Experimental data are computed as the mean ± standard deviation.
Table 1 Polyphenolic content of the prepared nanopwders.
Samples TPC (mg GAE/g) TFC (mg QE/g) PA (mg CE/g)
Ag nanoparticles 30.55 ± 0.54 350.30 ± 0.05 160.12 ± 0.12 AgPt nanoparticles 15.21 ± 0.32 130.41 ± 0.13 68.38 ± 0.42
Fig. 4. Antioxidant properties of the Ag and AgPt nanoparticles, DPPH (A) and ABTS (B).

sections.heading: 3.3. Antioxidant activity
sections.text: The antioxidant properties of the bio-synthesized Ag nanoparticles and AgPt nanoparticles was investigated by DPPH, and ABTS assays. For this test, standard sample is Ascorbic acid. The antioxidant abilities of Ag nanoparticles and AgPt nanoparticles are illustrated in Fig. 4. The bio nanoparticles samples demonstrated significance potential in scavenging activity with sample dose-dependent behavior. The AgPt nanoparticles have the highest antioxidant properties (IC50 13.87 and 19.49 μg/mL for DPPH and ABTS). The inhibition of DPPH radicals of bio-synthesized AgPt nanoparticles was higher than the ABTS radical. In this analysis, the H+ atom can be break the free radical chains. The antioxidant properties depicted by bio-synthesized nano materials due to the antioxidant potential of ethanolic of Crocus sativus L. extract as capping agents [30].

sections.heading: 3.4. Antibacterial and antifungal activity
sections.text:
The antimicrobial properties of the prepared AgPt nanoparticles was investigated against E. coli, E. faecalis and A. niger. The control group
had nanoparticles under similar method. As illustrated in Table 2, the bio-synthesized AgPt nanoparticles displayed great antimicrobial properties toward the pathogens. The results showed that the minimum inhibitory concentration (MIC) of the bio-synthesized AgPt nanoparticles had the strongest inhibitory properties the E. faecalis (29.2 ± 0.11 μg/mL), compared to E. coli and A. niger as 100.1 ± 0.32 and 127 ± 0.13 μg/mL, respectively. The MIC data depicted a two-fold inhibitory properties by the AgPt nanoparticles. In addition, the lowly inhibition was obtained in the drug resistant bacteria. Ruiz et al., [35] presented the antimicrobial influences of bimetallic nanoparticles and obtained increased inhibitory performance toward main pathogen bacteria.

sections.heading: 3.5. Cytotoxic efficiency
sections.text:
The cytotoxic influence of the Ag nanoparticles and AgPt nanoparticles toward normal human breast cancer cells (MCF-7) and embryonic kidney cells (HEK 293) were conducted. As illustrated in Fig. 5, the cytotoxic effect of Ag nanoparticles and AgPt nanoparticles was observed for HEK 293 cells. Two nanomaterials are non-toxic for HEK
293 (~ 60% cell viability with 12.0 μg/mL). The Ag nanoparticles and AgPt nanoparticles showed the lethal dose (LD50) value of 54.5 μg/mL and 60.0 μg/mL, respectively. The cytotoxic effect for MCF-7 cells was similar to HEK 293 cell. The AgPt nanoparticles indicated substantial cytotoxic influence compared to Ag nanoparticles (Fig. 5). Table 3 depicts the LD50 of 8.36 ± 0.12 and 20.28 ± 0.19 μg/mL were found for AgPt nanoparticles, and Ag nanoparticles in MCF-7 cell. The results confirms the AgPt nanoparticles indicating a higher cytotoxic influence in cancerous compared to normal cells [32]. The several factors have effect on selective cytotoxic mechanism, such as the physicochemical properties, tightly packed AgPt systems, and influences of unique system from two metal and extract [32].

sections.heading: 3.6. Catalysis test
sections.text:
The catalytic activity of the Ag nanoparticles and AgPt nanoparticles on degradation of methyl orange (MO) was studied by determining the residual MO concentration via UV–vis spectrophotometer at various time reaction (Fig. 6). The catalytic removal of dyes by sodium borohydride in presence of Ag nanoparticles and AgPt nanoparticles is broadly used to study the catalytic performance of the prepared nano samples. The catalytic removal of dyes in via sodium borohydride without the prepared nano samples depicted no change in the reduction of dye. The catalysis degradation of dyes was determined via the Ag nanoparticles and AgPt nano catalyst and sodium borohydride (Fig. 6), and evaluated the percent degradation. As can be seen, the catalytic activity of AgPt nanoparticles (96.68%), was higher than the Ag nanoparticles (70.5%). The reusability experiment shows the five cycles almost manifests similar catalytic efficiency of AgPt nanoparticles in compared the Ag nanoparticles (Fig. 6C), due to the active surface are of AgPt nanoparticles.
The catalytic activity of the bio-synthesized samples was studied to terms kinetic for the dye degradation [36–38]. The results showed the catalytic degradation of dye was followed pseudo–first–order kinetics. The kinetic rate (k) of dye removal was determined. The highest degradation rate of MB was determined in presence of AgPt nanoparticles (k = 1.028min−1) compared to Ag nanoparticles (k = 0.684min−1). Among the prepared samples, AgPt nanoparticles catalysts showed the most activity for degradation of the dyes.
The organic dye removal by NaBH4 with the AgPt nanoparticles as catalyst was evaluated. BH4− can be dissociate to generate hydrogen and e− in solutions. The main mechanism of dye reduction is e− can be generated by AgPt nanoparticles and it imports AgPt nanoparticles induced move of e− from BH4− ion to dye compounds. The AgPt nanoparticles can be reduced the activation energy, and the kinetic barrier for the donor/acceptor. Moreover, the plant extract bio-synthesized AgPt nanoparticles could have extra catalytic performance due to presence of plant biomolecules as matrix for chemical process and improved the catalyzed reaction rates.][39,40].

sections.heading: 4. Conclusions
sections.text:
This research presents the green synthesis of AgPt nanoparticles from ethanolic extract of Crocus sativus L. The size particles with spherical shape was found 36.0 nm, and negative zeta potential data (−29.5 mV), which that depicted the AgPt nanoparticles stability. The AgPt nanoparticles represented a substantial antioxidant properties with DPPH and ABTS radicals, compared to Ag nanoparticles and ascorbic acid. In addition, the AgPt nanoparticles indicated the antimicrobial properties with dose-dependent rout, and selective cytotoxicity properties against cancer compared to normal cells. The results indicated that AgPt nanoparticles possessed better catalytic activity as compared to Ag nanoparticles, due to the capping of the phytochemicals and synergistic effect. The bio-prepared AgPt nanoparticles can be applied in biomedical application as there is improvement in antioxidant properties.
Declaration of Competing Interest
The authors declare that they have no known competing financial interests or personal relationships that could have appeared to influence the work reported in this paper.

metadata.abstractText: In this project, silver‐platinum (AgPt) nanoparticles were prepared by using the Crocus sativus L. plant ethanolic extract. The AgPt nanoparticles were characterized by applying the various method as ultraviolet-visible and infrared spectroscopy, electron microscopy, and X-ray diffraction analysis. The morphology structural indicated that the AgPt nanoparticles were spherical particles with diameter about 36.0 nm. The FTIR spectroscopy shows the efficient stabilization of the AgPt nanoparticles by phytoconstituents. The Ag and AgPt nanoparticles have polyphenolic content, lower than the flavonoids and proanthocyanins contents. The AgPt nanoparticles depicted the highest antioxidant properties compared to the Ag nanoparticles and ascorbic acid. The results showed that the AgPt nanoparticles had a high antioxidant properties. In addition, the AgPt nanoparticles demonstrated the substantial antimicrobial and cytotoxic activities against pathogenic microbes and MCF-7 breast cancer cell line. The environmental chemistry analysis depicts that methyl orange can be degraded from water by catalytic degradation process with sodium borohydride. The AgPt nanoparticles were prosperous in catalytic degrading methyl orange following a first order kinetic model.
